One of the more confusing "simple" explanations I've ever come across.  I think he was trying to explain why energy is emitted from hot objects like incandescent light bulb filaments in the form of particles called photons which each have an energy content that is proportional to their frequency.  It turns out that the higher frequency photons of visible light are emitted from electrons making transitions between orbitals of the tungsten atoms in the light bulb's filament with the energy and frequency of a photon increasing as the energy difference of the two orbitals it moves between increases.  The closer two orbitals are to a tungsten atom's nucleus, the greater the difference in their energies which is emitted as a photon whenever an excited electron drops down from the higher to the lower energy orbital.  As the filament heats up, its atoms start vibrating more violently and their random impacts against each other will be able to knock electrons from lower energy to higher energy orbitals that are closer and closer to the nucleus and have greater and greater energy differences.  When those electrons then return to their starting orbitals they will give off photons of higher and higher energy and frequency as a consequence.  This is why the light emitted by a hot object experiences a shift in the average energy and frequency of its photons toward higher values as the object gets hotter.

Real story of quantization is: Planck was obsessed with explaining entropy formula.Using Wien's law of spectral density he got a formula for entropy of a single black body oscillator in 1899. The law was sometimes called Wien-Planck's law. Except the formula wasn't correct at low frequencies. The problem was in the definition of oscillator entropy. In 1900 Planck derived a formula which was agreeing with experiments even on low frequencies. But he did not use quantization yet. In November 1900 he realized that he needed to find more fundamental derivation of entropy law. He used Boltzmann's equation for entropy S=k*logW . To find W Planck had to count how many ways an energy can be distributed across a set of oscillators. That's when he first thought of "energy elements". Energy of the black body oscillators is divided into a finite portions of energy. Quantization was born.

The same thing happens in every other type of oscillation, also. When you strike a piano string, you hear much more of the fundamental mode. But if you strike it harder, you hear more of the higher harmonics. But no matter how hard you hit it, the higher ones tucker out. It's not because they are quantized. It's because a very small oscillation in the higher harmonics is just as energetic as a great oscillation of the lower ones. Same thing with EM waves.

A smaller change in the field results in a wave of greater length, and a greater change in the field results in a wave of shorter length. I suspect that this seemed illogical at the time, because there was a prejudice that a greater change in the field should have resulted in a greater _amplitude_, rather than a wave of _shorter length_. That seems reasonable, but it just happens to be wrong. 

Even in classical EM, creating a short wavelength requires more energy than a long one.

I've always felt that the resolution to the so-called "ultraviolet catastrophe" (the cookie problem) was actually dealt with pretty well by classical EM (EM in which light is carried in waves). For that reason, I don't believe it's a great way to introduce QED. The so-called catastrophe doesn't come up in classical EM because even there, a classical EM wave  is initiated by a change in the field, for example, by an electron changing states from one orbital to another one.

You're right - 1/infinity is not equal to zero.  You can't explicitly divide an amount by infinity as infinity isn't a number, it's a concept.

However, instead of direct arithmetic, use calculus and limits.
Let's say that f(x) = 1/x.  As x approaches zero, f(x) approaches infinity, although it never actually does. 

As x approaches infinity, f(x) approaches zero.  Intuitively, we can say that lim x→∞ f(x) = 0.

No it's not fallacious. You're right that inf is not a number but just expresses a diverging limit. But in the same way that 0/0 could be used to represent a limit of two vanishing quantities (sinx/x for example, as x -> 0), inf^inf can be used to represent a limit of one divergent quantity to the power of another. (Of course, unlike the case of 0/0 or 0^0, here the result does not depend on which limit you use these symbols to represent. inf^inf=inf, always.)
Atomic theory describes this in terms of electrons getting bumped up into higher energy levels by thermal excitations, then releasing energy as light when they transition back to their ground states.

Hopefully this helps:
Objects are made up of particles that are constantly bouncing into each other. When particles bounce they give off light waves. Objects at higher temperatures are defined as those with particles which *on average* bounce more violently than objects at lower temperatures (have higher average energy). The energy given to the light wave depends on the violence of bounce. Light waves with a particular amount of energy have particular wavelength and frequency.

Picture a trampoline. What would happen if you put a bowling ball in the middle? The trampoline would bend inward towards the ball, which would sink due to it's weight. Then imagine you put a marble somewhere else on the trampoline, say near the edge. What would happen? The marble would roll down the slope (or "bend") in the trampoline towards the bowling ball.
This scenario is not an actual example of gravity, but it's meant to help one visualize what is meant by the "bending" of spacetime.

if we are going at say 0.9c, and we shoot a bullet forward also at 0.9c, we discover via the formula that it doesnt attain an overall speed of 1.8c but rather 
(0.9c + 0.9c)/(1 + [0.9]²) ≈ 0.994c
Now, to you, the space traveler, everything looks normal. However, a stationary observer would note that you're suffering from the Fitzgerald contraction: (1) time slows down for you (although you dont realize it), and (2) you and your spaceship get compressed like an accordion along your axis of travel

You probably think that if you're standing in a bus moving at speed u, and you walk forward at speed v, your total forward speed w is expressed by the straightforward sum u + v. In reality, what we might call "addition of velocities" is governed by the equation 
w = (u + v)/(1 + uv/c²) 
where c² is the speed of light squared. At low speeds, uv/c² is pretty close to 0, so the equation reduces down to the familiar w = u + v. However (check next reply for continuation)

Photons of higher frequencies are composed of more energy than lower frequencies

where h = planck's constant, f = frequency, λ = wavelength, c = speed of light
  
Also, frequency is inverse of wavelength f = c/λ

But in quantum world, electrons don't get to choose to linearly scale up their moving energy, they jump from level to level depends on energy input. Since it's not a "stable" status to get excited, they tend to "give up" energy to return to more stable level, and when that happens they emit photons with specific wave length depends on how much energy they gave up. Thus energy->light waves.

Take the inverse of 0. You get (1/0). As you know that doesn't exist. However if you take the limit of that you'll realize that it's actually getting closer and closer to infinity and negative infinity. The definition of an inverse is that if you multiply an inverse by the original number, you'll get 1. So infinity times 0 would equal 1.

Although in all honesty that isn't quite true because infinity isn't really a number, so you can't expect to do normal algebra with it and have it make sense.
